title-group.article-title: Advanced magnetic resonance imaging of neuromyelitis optica: a multiparametric approach

abstract.p: Background: Several authors have used advanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) techniques to investigate whether patients with neuromyelitis optica (NMO) have occult damage in normal-appearing brain tissue, similarly to multiple sclerosis (MS). To date, the literature contains no data derived from the combined use of several advanced MRI techniques in the same NMO subjects.
Objective: We set out to determine whether occult damage could be detected in the normal-appearing brain tissue of a small group of patients with NMO using a multiparametric MRI approach.

Methods: Eight female patients affected by NMO (age range 44–58 years) and seven sex- and age-matched healthy controls were included. The techniques used on a 1.5 T MRI imaging scanner were magnetization transfer imaging, diffusion tensor imaging, tract-based spatial statistics, spectroscopy and voxel-based morphometry in order to analyse normal-appearing white matter and normal-appearing grey matter.

Results: Structural and metabolic parameters showed no abnormalities in normal-appearing white matter of patients with NMO. Conversely, tract-based spatial statistics demonstrated a selective alteration of the optic pathways and the lateral geniculate nuclei. Diffusion tensor imaging values in the normal-appearing grey matter were found to be significantly different in the patients with NMO versus the healthy controls. Moreover, voxel-based morphometry analysis demonstrated a significant density and volume reduction of the sensorimotor cortex and the visual cortex.

Conclusions: Our data disclosed occult structural damage in the brain of patients with NMO, predominantly involving regions connected with motor and visual systems. This damage seems to be the direct consequence of transsynaptic degeneration triggered by lesions of the optic nerve and spine.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Devic’s neuromyelitis optica (NMO), which can be mono- or multiphasic1, is an inflammatory demyelinating disease of the central nervous system consisting of acute severe transverse myelitis and optic neuritis (ON). The updated NMO diagnostic criteria2 contain two major new elements. These are related to the discovery of a specific biomarker for the disease that might have a pathogenetic role, namely anti-aquaporin 4 antibody (Ab antiaqp4),3 and to the possible presence of brain parenchymal abnormalities enabling differentiation of NMO from multiple sclerosis (MS)4-6 on conventional imaging.

Several authors have used advanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) techniques to investigate whether patients with NMO show the occult damage in normal-appearing brain tissue (NABT)7-11 that is observed in MS. The first study, using magnetization transfer imaging (MTI),7 did not find any occult damage in the NABT of eight patients with recurrent NMO (RNMO); more recently, MTI and diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) performed in 10 patients with NMO detected reduced magnetization transfer ratios (MTRs) and increased mean diffusivity (MD) values for normal-appearing grey matter (NAGM), but not for normal-appearing white matter (NAWM).8 Yu et al.,9 using DTI in 16 patients with RNMO, found global damage in the brain tissue (both NAWM and NAGM) of these patients. Moreover, after manually selecting, a priori, specific WM areas connected with the spinal tracts or optic nerve and some GM areas representative of each single lobe, abnormalities were found that could be partially explained by secondary degeneration. Neither of the two MR spectroscopy (1H-MRS) studies present in the literature, performed with different magnets (1.5 vs. 3 T) and using different techniques (single vs. multivoxel), reported metabolic changes in NMO brain tissue.10,11

To date, the literature contains no data derived from the combined use of several advanced MRI techniques in the same NMO subjects. In view of this, we set out to determine whether occult damage could be detected in the NABT of a small group of patients with NMO, using a multiparametric MRI approach. The techniques used were MTI, DTI, tract-based spatial statistics (TBSS), 1H-MRS and voxel-based morphometry (VBM).

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: Seven female patients affected by clinically definite NMO, diagnosed according to the Wingerchuck criteria,2 and one with a single episode of ON associated with NMO-IgG positivity (considered an NMO spectrum disorder) were included in this study (Table 1). Seven sex- and age-matched healthy individuals (t-test, p = 0.27) were recruited as the control group (HCs). A local ethical committee approved this prospective study and all subjects gave their written consent.

sec.p: The patients had a mean age of 50 years (range 44–58), a mean age at disease onset of 36.1 years (± 10.2), and a mean disease duration of 14 years (±10.25). All the patients but one had a relapsing disease course; the remaining patient, having experienced only one episode of ON, showed a monophasic disease course. The ON in the patients with RMNO was unilateral in three cases and bilateral in one; myelitis was present in all the patients with RMNO. The number of relapses in these patients ranged from 5–25.

The mean interval between the onset of the disease and the execution of the advanced MRI techniques analysed in this paper was 13.25 years (range 1–32). Brain MRI was negative in all but five cases, in whom only small, bilateral, subcortical lesions with no gadolinium enhancement were found. In all the patients except the one with monophasic disease, spine MRI disclosed at least one lesion extending over three segments.

Disease severity was calculated using the score constructed by Wingerchuck et al.12 at two different time points: the time of maximum degree of disability for each single functional system, and the time of MRI examination. Four patients showed severe, predominantly bilateral impairment of the visual system in the acute phase of ON (the mean score of the involved eye was 5.5), while the other patients showed moderate impairment (mean score 3). At the time of MRI most patients presented a moderate-to-good recovery of visual function (mean score 1), and only one patient was found to be almost blind bilaterally.

The motor system at nadir in the patients with myelitis was markedly impaired in three subjects (mean score 4.5) and moderately impaired in the other four (mean score 3). All the patients achieved a partial motor recovery over time (mean score 3). The recovery of sensory and sphincteric functions showed a similar time course.

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis, performed in seven cases and at least twice in the acute phase, showed only mild lymphocytic pleocytosis and hyperproteinorrachia; six of the seven RMNO patients had oligoclonal bands in the first analysis, but these disappeared over time in two cases.

Testing for NMO-IgG and Ab antiaqp4 was performed in all patients. Both investigations were both positive in three patients and negative in one; three cases were NMO-IgG negative and Ab antiaqp4 positive, while the last case was MO-IgG positive and Ab antiaqp4 negative.

sec.title: MR imaging and MR spectroscopy
sec.p: MR images of the brain were obtained using an eight-channel 1.5 T MRI scanner (Philips Gyroscan, Koninklijke, The Netherlands). An eight-channel head (SENSE) third-party coil was used to acquire the following sequences: 1) axial 3D high resolution (HIRES) T1-WI using a fast gradient echo (fast field echo, FFE) (TR = 25 ms, TE = 4.6 ms, slice thickness = 1.6 mm, voxel dimension = 0.97 mm, FOV = 250 mm, reconstruction matrix = 256 × 256, number of slices = 160); 2) axial DP-T2 spin echo (SE) sequence (TR = 25 ms, TE = 4.6 ms, slice thickness = 1.6 mm, voxel dimension = 0.97 mm, FOV = 250 mm, reconstruction matrix = 256 × 256, number of slices = 160); 3) axial DTI pulse gradient spin echo (PGSE) echo planar pulse sequence (TR = 9.17 s, TE = 68 ms, b-values: 0–800 s/mm2, slice thickness = 2.33 mm, gap = 0 mm, voxel dimension = 2 mm, FOV = 224 mm, reconstruction matrix = 112 × 112, number of slices = 55, number of averages = 3), with a total of 16 images acquired, 15 with noncollinear diffusion weighting gradients with a b-value of 800 s/mm2 and one without diffusion weighting; 4) 2D FFE T1-WI using FFE with and without an off-resonance radiofrequency saturation pulse (MTI, offset frequency = 1.5 kHz, TR/TE = 650/10, flip angle = 30°, 22 axial 3 mm-thick slices, matrix = 256 × 192, FOV = 250 × 188).

1H-MRS was performed to assess the metabolic pattern in the NAWM. Measurements were performed parallel to axial T1- and T2-weighted sections, with routine automatic adjustments applied before data acquisition. A rectangular voxel of interest (13 × 11 × 2 cm) was selected in the frontoparietal WM well above the lateral ventricles; special care was taken to avoid skull and subcutaneous tissue contamination. Chemical shift imaging, using a 90 Hz chemical shift selective pulse for water suppression, was performed with the following parameters: TE = 288 ms, TM interval = 30 ms; TR = 2000 ms; acquisition matrix = 192 × 192; data size = 1024; spectrum amplitude = 1000 Hz; NA = 3, FOV = 180 mm, Lorentzian filter. To obtain an internal quantification reference, additional scanning was performed with the same timing and geometric parameters but without water suppression. The total acquisition time of the spectroscopic sequences was < 15 min.

sec.title: Post-analysis
sec.p: Image analysis was performed on an off-line workstation by four operators (GP, FP and MP, with 5 years of experience in MRI post-analysis, and DT, with 3 years’ experience in brain lesion measurements).

sec.title: Lesion measurements
sec.p: Brain lesions, when present, were identified on DP-T2-weighted images and masked using a semi-automated edge-detection contouring-threshold technique implemented in the Jim image analysis package, Version 5.0 (Xinapse Systems Ltd., Northants, UK, www.xinapse.com).

sec.title: Brain tissue segmentation
sec.p: GM, WM and CSF were segmented with the FAST automated algorithm13 from the 3D HIRES T1-WI, after the N3 non-parametric signal uniformity correction14,15 and the lesion regions of interest (ROIs) masking.

sec.title: Magnetic transfer tissue-specific histogram analysis
sec.p: MTR maps were calculated on as: MTR(%) = (M0 - Mmt)/M0,16 M0 and Mmt being the 2D FFE T1-WI sequences with and without off-resonance MT saturation pulse, respectively. Histograms for NABT and NAGM and NAWM were produced. For each histogram, the average MTR, peak height, peak position and full width at half height (FWHH) were calculated.

sec.title: MD and fractional anisotropy histogram analysis
sec.p: DTI data were processed using the FDT FMRIB Software Library (FSL, http://www.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl).17 A correction for motion and Eddy current distortions was applied, prior to the reconstruction of the MD and fractional anisotropy (FA) maps.18 Histograms for NABT, NAGM and NAWM were produced for the MD and FA maps and average MD and FA, peak height, peak position and full width at half maximum (FWHM) were calculated.

sec.title: TBSS
sec.p: The TBSS algorithm allows for a track specific DTI processing, able therefore to control for global and partial volume related effects. The TBSS pipeline was run along the following steps:19 1) masking of all lesions identified on the anatomical images with a missing value tag (Not-a-Number, NaN) in the MD and FA maps; 2) non-linear registration of all FA maps to the subject closest to the group mean, in order to minimize the warping required; 3) affine transformation onto the standard MNI space; 4) generation and thresholding of the mean FA map to obtain a binary skeleton mask identifying the voxels to be used in all subsequent processing. The final voxelwise analysis was performed using FSL’s randomize program,20 choosing the threshold-free cluster enhancement (TFCE) option,21 which combines general linear model (GLM) testing with permutation inference statistics.

sec.title: VBM
sec.p: HIRES data were analysed using the SPM5 (Wellcome Department of Cognitive Neurology, www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk) toolbox for MATLAB 7.9 (The MathWorks, Natick, MA, USA). VBM processing was performed as described by Good et al.,22 along the following steps: 1) extraction of the brain parenchyma and segmentation in GM and WM; 2) normalization of GM/WM maps onto the MNI template; 3) multiplication (modulation) of the voxel intensities in the GM/WM maps by the determinant of the Jacobian derived from the spatial normalization step: modulated data provide regional differences in the absolute amount (volume) of GM/WM, whereas non-modulated data correspond to differences in concentration of GM/WM (per unit volume in native space);23 4) each normalized, segmented, modulated image is smoothed with an 8 mm FWHM Gaussian kernel. The voxelwise statistics on the resulting maps was performed applying a GLM24 and including age as nuisance variable for GM and WM comparisons. The resulting t-statistic maps, corrected for multiple comparisons using family-wise error correction, were thresholded at a p < 0.05.

sec.title: 1H-MRS analysis
sec.p: Quantification of the spectra was performed off-line in the time domain using the jMRUI software package.25 Signals from frontal and parietal WM voxels matching previous masking of lesion load were selected. Choline (Cho), creatine (Cr), and N-acetil-aspartate (NAA) signals were quantified by means of the advanced method for accurate, robust, and efficient spectral fitting (AMARES)26 using prior knowledge basis functions. The residue water signal was removed using a Hankel–Lanczos singular value decomposition filter prior to the quantification. Metabolite ratios with respect to Cr were calculated.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The Student t-test for non-paired data was used to compare both MD, FA and MT histogram-derived measurements and metabolite ratios (NAA/Cr and Cho/Cr) between patients with NMO and HCs. Moreover, to adjust for multiple comparisons and to avoid type II errors, the significance level was set at p ≤ 0.01 for each test. Analyses were performed by using Stata version 10 (Stata Corp, College Station, TX, USA).

sec.title: DTI analysis
sec.p: The comparison of MD histogram-derived measurements (average MD, peak height, peak position and FWHH for NABT, NAWM and NAGM) showed no statistically significant differences between NMO patients and HCs. Comparison of the FA histogram-derived measurements confirmed this result for NABT and NAWM; instead, the NAGM average FA value was found to differ significantly between the NMO patients and the HCs (0.16 ± 0.01 vs. 0.14 ± 0.01, p = 0.002) as well as the mean peak height (67.15 ± 7.28 vs. 79.48 ± 4.72, p = 0.002) (Table 2).

sec.p: TBSS analysis showed a significantly lowered FA (p < 0.05) along the pathway of the optic radiation bilaterally (Figure 1A), also involving the lateral geniculate nuclei (Figure 1B). Apart from the presence of significant clusters of locally reduced FA in the WM of the right superior temporal gyrus (Figure 1A), no other pathway seemed to be involved. All significances are lost if results are corrected for multiple comparisons, almost certainly due to the relatively small subject population.

caption.p: Voxel-wise diffusion tensor imaging analysis showing a significantly lowered fractional anisotropy (FA) along the pathway of the optic radiation bilaterally (A) and involvement of both lateral geniculate nuclei (B).

sec.title: VBM analysis
sec.p: GM analysis showed a significant reduction of both density and volume in the patients with NMO compared with the HCs, predominantly in the motor (Figure 2A) and visual (Figure 2B) cortex, and in regions associated with executive and language functions. In detail, bilateral involvement of the GM was found to correspond to Brodmann areas 4, 6, 8, 9, 10, 17, 18, 21, and 40. No change was observed in the WM instead. These results are summarized in Table 3.

sec.title: 1H-MRS analysis
sec.p: As shown in Figure 3, between-group comparisons of the NAA/Cr and Cho/Cr ratios did not reveal any significant difference, when considering either total NAWM or frontal and parietal NAWM.

sec.title: MTI analysis
sec.p: Analysis of MTR in the cortical and deep GM and WM did not reveal differences between the patients with NMO and the HCs (Table 2).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Traditionally, NMO was considered part of the MS spectrum even though the selective involvement of the optic nerve and spine with sparing of the brain argued against this interpretation. However, the identification of a humoral marker specific to NMO, namely Ab antiaqp4,3 has now put an end to this debate. A few reports of brain lesions in patients with NMO,4-6 not corresponding to the MS diagnostic criteria, led some authors to hypothesize that there could also be occult damage in the NABT of patients with NMO.7-11 In an attempt to shed light on this issue, we examined the NABT of patients with NMO using a combination of advanced MRI techniques.

In accordance with the findings of other authors,8 our analysis of the NAWM showed no differences in MD, FA, MTR and VBM between NMO patients and HCs; conversely, Yu et al.9 found higher MD and FA values in NMO, even though the differences between absolute values were extremely subtle, as the authors themselves pointed out. Voxelwise analysis of FA in our study demonstrated a selective, bilateral alteration of the optic pathways also involving the lateral geniculate nuclei. This finding might suggest anterograde degeneration secondary to an optic nerve lesion not detectable on conventional MRI,27 despite the investigation of the correlation between FA and visual function that would be necessary for supporting this interpretation. On the other hand, the explanation for the apparent sparing of all the other pathways, including the pyramidal functional system, which was impaired in all the patients, may lie in a technical limitation of TBSS, which is relatively less sensitive in the feet-to-head as opposed to the axial direction, which corresponds to the acquisition plain for the DTI–EPI sequence.

In our study, MD and FA in the NAGM were found to be slightly, but significantly, different in the patients with NMO versus the HCs. This finding agrees with the results of previous studies.8,9 Specifically, Rocca et al.8 demonstrated global GM involvement, while Yu et al.,9 by means of manual ROI analysis, also demonstrated focal parietal GM damage. The results of our VBM analysis demonstrated a significant density and volume reduction of the sensorimotor cortex and the visual cortex, consistent with the hypotheses, respectively, of retrograde and anterograde degeneration of the specific pathways deriving from the macroscopically damaged spine and optic nerve. Another interesting finding was the involvement of the frontotemporal circuits connected with language and executive functions, which was consistent with the specific patterns seen in cognitive disorders recently reported in NMO.28

As for structural information, 1H-MRS showed that there are no metabolic changes in the NAWM in patients with NMO, confirming previous results by Bichuetti et al.10 and Aboul-Enein et al.11 Our data were obtained using the same multivoxel technique used in the more recent study,11 but on a 1.5 T magnet. Taken together, the results obtained in these three small cohorts seem to support the hypothesis that NMO is characterized by the absence of an occult diffuse degenerative process in the NAWM, strengthening the concept that NMO and MS are different pathological entities. Future applications of 1H-MRS on specific WM tracts, such as optic pathways, and GM regions, may confirm the presence of selective brain structure involvement, as indicated by our structural data.

Indeed, our results highlighted the presence of occult structural damage in the brains of patients with NMO: we found a selective impairment of optic pathways in the WM, while the GM was predominantly involved in regions connected with motor and visual systems. This damage seems to be the direct consequence of transsynaptic degeneration triggered by lesions of the optic nerve and spine rather than an inflammatory–degenerative process of the brain per se.
